verses.text: Now in the church at Antioch there were prophets and teachers: Barnabas, Simeon who was called Niger, Lucius of Cyrene, Manaen (who had been brought up with Herod the tetrarch), and Saul.
verses.comment: This introduction names the prominent leaders in the early church at Antioch. The reference to prophets and teachers highlights the diversity of spiritual gifts operating in the church (see 1 Cor. 12:28).

verses.text: As they were worshiping the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said, 'Set apart for me Barnabas and Saul for the work to which I have called them.'
verses.comment: The Holy Spirit directly calls Barnabas and Saul (Paul) for a specific mission. This early example of ordination for service demonstrates how the church discerns vocations through prayer, worship, and obedience to the Spirit.

verses.text: Then, after fasting and praying, they laid their hands on them and sent them off.
verses.comment: The laying on of hands signifies commissioning with authority and the impartation of blessing, a practice rooted in Old Testament tradition (Num. 27:18–23), and continued by the apostles.

verses.text: So, being sent out by the Holy Spirit, they went down to Seleucia, and from there they sailed to Cyprus.
verses.comment: Their mission begins under the direction of the Spirit, affirming that all true missionary activity is led by God.

verses.text: When they arrived at Salamis, they proclaimed the word of God in the synagogues of the Jews. And they also had John as their assistant.
verses.comment: Missionary work begins in the Jewish synagogues, following the pattern of 'to the Jew first, and also to the Greek' (Rom. 1:16).

verses.text: When they had gone through the whole island as far as Paphos, they found a certain magician, a Jewish false prophet named Bar-Jesus.
verses.comment: Bar-Jesus is linked to the kind of syncretistic Jewish-Gentile magic found in the Mediterranean world, which undermines apostolic authority.

verses.text: He was with the proconsul, Sergius Paulus, an intelligent man. The proconsul called for Barnabas and Saul and sought to hear the word of God.
verses.comment: The Roman governor’s interest in the word of God shows the Gospel’s appeal to both Jew and Gentile.

verses.text: But Elymas the magician (for that is the meaning of his name) opposed them, seeking to turn the proconsul away from the faith.
verses.comment: Elymas resists the Gospel, embracing secular power and occultism in opposition to the apostolic missionaries.

verses.text: But Saul, who is also called Paul, filled with the Holy Spirit, fixed his gaze on him
verses.comment: Here Saul is first called Paul, indicating his missionary identity to the Gentiles. The Spirit empowers him for bold action.

verses.text: and said, 'You son of the devil, enemy of all righteousness, full of all deceit and villainy, will you not stop making crooked the straight paths of the Lord?'
verses.comment: Paul’s words echo John the Baptist and the prophets who call for true repentance and oppose spiritual deception.

verses.text: Now, look! The hand of the Lord is upon you, and you will be blind and unable to see the sun for a time.' Immediately mist and darkness fell upon him, and he went about seeking people to lead him by the hand.
verses.comment: Paul, who himself was struck blind at his conversion, now enacts a similar sign, underscoring divine judgment and mercy.

verses.text: Then the proconsul, when he saw what had happened, believed, being astonished at the teaching of the Lord.
verses.comment: Miracles serve as signs confirming apostolic authority and leading to faith in Christ (see Mark 16:20).

verses.text: Now Paul and his companions set sail from Paphos and came to Perga in Pamphylia. But John left them and returned to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: John Mark’s departure later becomes a point of contention, showing the human dimension in early missionary work.

verses.text: But they went on from Perga and arrived at Antioch in Pisidia. On the Sabbath day they went into the synagogue and sat down.
verses.comment: Paul continues the custom of preaching in synagogues first, signifying the continuity between God's Old and New Covenant people.

verses.text: After the reading from the Law and the Prophets, the synagogue leaders sent a message to them, saying, 'Brothers, if you have any word of encouragement for the people, speak.'
verses.comment: This reflects the openness of synagogue worship to guests and shows Scripture's central role in worship.

verses.text: So Paul stood up, and motioning with his hand, said: 'Men of Israel, and you who fear God, listen.'
verses.comment: Paul addresses both Jews and 'God-fearers' (Gentile worshipers sympathetic to Judaism), fulfilling the expanding scope of salvation.

verses.text: 'The God of this people Israel chose our fathers, and made the people great during their stay in the land of Egypt, and with an uplifted arm He led them out of it.
verses.comment: Paul’s sermon interprets Israel’s history as fulfillment leading to Christ. God’s sovereign election and acts in salvation history are highlighted.

verses.text: For about forty years He put up with them in the wilderness.
verses.comment: Paul gently rebukes Israel’s history of disobedience, setting the stage for the Messiah’s coming.

verses.text: And after destroying seven nations in the land of Canaan, He gave their land to them as an inheritance.
verses.comment: God’s gift of the promised land is the background for understanding Christ’s inheritance for his people.

verses.text: All this took about 450 years. And after that He gave them judges until Samuel the prophet.
verses.comment: The history of judges and Samuel leads to the establishment of monarchy, which points towards Christ as true King.

verses.text: Then they asked for a king, and God gave them Saul the son of Kish, a man of the tribe of Benjamin, for forty years.
verses.comment: Israel’s desire for a king is fulfilled first in Saul, but ultimately in Christ the true shepherd-king.

verses.text: And when He had removed him, He raised up David to be their king, of whom He testified and said, 'I have found David the son of Jesse, a man after My own heart, who will do all My will.'
verses.comment: God’s covenant with David foreshadows the Messiah, who would rule forever (see Luke 1:32-33).

verses.text: From this man’s descendants God has brought to Israel a Savior, Jesus, as He promised.
verses.comment: Jesus is presented as fulfillment of messianic prophecy and hope—a central Christological theme.

verses.text: Before His coming, John had proclaimed a baptism of repentance to all the people of Israel.
verses.comment: John the Baptist prepares the way for Jesus by calling for repentance—a spiritual preparation for Christ's kingdom.

verses.text: As John was finishing his course, he said, 'Who do you suppose I am? I am not he. But behold, one is coming after me, the sandals of whose feet I am not worthy to untie.'
verses.comment: John humbly testifies to Christ’s superiority, pointing to His divine mission (see also Mark 1:7).

verses.text: 'Brothers, sons of Abraham’s family, and those among you who fear God, to us has been sent this word of salvation.'
verses.comment: The Gospel message is for both Jews and Gentiles who fear God, emphasizing the universality of salvation.

verses.text: For those who live in Jerusalem and their rulers, because they did not recognize Him nor understand the voices of the Prophets read every Sabbath, fulfilled them by condemning Him.
verses.comment: In rejecting Christ, Israel’s leaders ironically fulfill the very Scriptures they read.

verses.text: And though they found in Him no guilt worthy of death, they asked Pilate to have Him executed.
verses.comment: Christ's innocence underlines his role as the blameless sacrificial Lamb (see Isa. 53:9).

verses.text: When they had carried out all that was written about Him, they took Him down from the tree and laid Him in a tomb.
verses.comment: Jesus’ passion and burial fulfill Old Testament prophecy about the Messiah’s suffering and death.

verses.text: But God raised Him from the dead.
verses.comment: Resurrection is proclaimed as the central event of salvation history, validating Jesus' identity and mission.

verses.text: And for many days He appeared to those who had come up with Him from Galilee to Jerusalem, who are now His witnesses to the people.
verses.comment: The resurrection appearances confirm the reality of the event, providing eyewitness testiomony at the heart of the Gospel.

verses.text: And we bring you the good news that what God promised to the fathers,
verses.comment: The Good News is the promised fulfillment of God’s ancient promises to the patriarchs.

verses.text: this He has fulfilled to us their children by raising Jesus, as also it is written in the second Psalm: 'You are My Son; today I have begotten You.'
verses.comment: Paul interprets Psalm 2 as fulfilled in the Resurrection, affirming Christ’s divine Sonship—a key doctrine of faith.

verses.text: And that He raised Him from the dead, no more to return to corruption, He has spoken in this way: 'I will give you the holy and sure blessings promised to David.'
verses.comment: Through Jesus, the everlasting promises to David are fulfilled in the resurrection—symbolizing incorruptible life for all united with Christ.

verses.text: Therefore He also says in another Psalm: 'You will not let Your Holy One see corruption.'
verses.comment: The resurrection is foreshadowed in the Psalms; Christ is uniquely preserved from decay, affirming his holiness.

verses.text: For David, after he had served the purpose of God in his own generation, fell asleep and was laid with his fathers and saw corruption;
verses.comment: Unlike David, Christ’s body did not experience decay, underscoring the uniqueness of His resurrection.

verses.text: but He whom God raised up did not see corruption.
verses.comment: This affirms the bodily resurrection of Jesus, a central reality for the hope of all Christians.

verses.text: Let it be known to you, brothers, that through this Man forgiveness of sins is proclaimed to you.
verses.comment: The forgiveness of sins is possible only through Jesus—hinting at the necessity of receiving God’s grace through Him.

verses.text: And by Him everyone who believes is justified from everything from which you could not be justified by the law of Moses.
verses.comment: Paul contrasts faith in Christ with the limitations of the Mosaic Law, echoing themes of grace, justification, and faith.

verses.text: Beware, then, lest what is said in the Prophets should come upon you:
verses.comment: Paul’s warning draws on prophetic tradition to emphasize the seriousness of rejecting the Gospel.

verses.text: 'Look, you scoffers, be amazed and perish; for I am doing a work in your days, a work that you will not believe, even if one tells it to you.'
verses.comment: Paul applies the words of Habakkuk, warning of unbelief and the consequences of rejecting God’s work in Christ.

verses.text: As they went out, the people begged that these things might be spoken to them again the next Sabbath.
verses.comment: The response reveals spiritual hunger for the Gospel, prompting continued instruction and participation in worship.

verses.text: And after the assembly was dismissed, many of the Jews and devout converts to Judaism followed Paul and Barnabas, who, as they spoke with them, urged them to continue in the grace of God.
verses.comment: Continuing in grace emphasizes perseverance—the ongoing nature of the believer’s life in Christ.

verses.text: The next Sabbath almost the whole city gathered to hear the word of the Lord.
verses.comment: Such overwhelming response prepares for both opposition and new opportunities for the Gospel’s advance.

verses.text: But when the Jews saw the crowds, they were filled with jealousy and began to contradict what was spoken by Paul, reviling him.
verses.comment: Opposition arises from envy, as the Good News breaks out beyond expected ethnic and religious boundaries.

verses.text: And Paul and Barnabas spoke out boldly, saying, 'It was necessary that the word of God should be spoken first to you. Since you reject it and judge yourselves unworthy of eternal life, behold, we are turning to the Gentiles.'
verses.comment: The program of mission shifts to include Gentiles, as was always God’s intention through Israel.

verses.text: For so the Lord has commanded us, saying, 'I have set you as a light for the Gentiles, that you may bring salvation to the ends of the earth.'
verses.comment: Fulfillment of Isaiah’s prophecy—salvation is to all peoples, through the apostles as Christ’s representatives.

verses.text: When the Gentiles heard this, they were glad and glorified the word of the Lord; and as many as were appointed to eternal life believed.
verses.comment: This verse points to God’s sovereign initiative in salvation—emphasizing predestination and the necessity of remaining steadfast in faith and the community of believers.

verses.text: And the word of the Lord was spreading throughout the whole region.
verses.comment: The message is not limited, but rapidly extends as the new covenant spreads outward from the apostles.

verses.text: But the Jews stirred up the devout women of prominence and the leading men of the city, and raised up a persecution against Paul and Barnabas, and drove them out of their district.
verses.comment: Opposition to apostolic teaching includes both civil and religious leaders; persecution often follows the true faith.

verses.text: But they shook off the dust from their feet against them and went to Iconium.
verses.comment: This gesture indicates that the missionaries did their duty and move on if the message is rejected—a sign of judgment mirroring Jesus’ instructions to his disciples.

verses.text: And the disciples were filled with joy and with the Holy Spirit.
verses.comment: Despite persecution, the community remains filled with joy and the Holy Spirit—evidence of God’s continuing presence, strengthening believers in faith, unity, and mission.
